At that time, the brÄhman again said to Sudhana:

Our king is perfect in the above various methods and pure deportment. He first enters the ritual arena to pay homage to the sages, seeking blessings and protection, and bestowing grace upon sentient beings;
Or he performs ancestral sacrifices, thinking of repaying his parents' kindness, teaching people to be filial and respectful, secretly benefiting the myriad directions;

Or he goes out on hunting expeditions, governing the people and inspecting the regions, leading the troops to accomplish his goals, and when his merit is complete, he returns in triumph, investigating the calamities of drought and flood, and personally rejoicing in the blessings.

At the time of sacrifice, single-mindedly and respectfully, without negligence, as if facing him directly, imagining his appearance, thinking of his teachings, moved to tears, offering with sincerity, without any private thoughts. For ministers in the country who have merit and virtue, the virtuous and good, those at home and those who have left home, those of great virtue and high age, those who are respected, after their passing, their portraits are painted, according to their deeds, various stupas and temples are established.

Our king is like this, day after day, inwardly with utmost sincerity, outwardly diligently serving with food, drink, wealth, treasures, and the most precious and wonderful things, making offerings and paying homage, never slacking off.
These ten kinds, from chewing tooth wood to making offerings, are completed in the first two parts of the day.
At sunrise, he first summons a good doctor to check on his well-being.
Throughout the day and night, he regulates his diet.

Next, he summoned the astronomers, weather forecasters, yin-yang experts, those in charge of wind and rain, the sun, stars, and moon, the calculations of planetary movements, the differences between correct and hidden appearances, calamities, blessings, and celebrations, and all the methods for dispelling them, without sincerity.
The secret matters that can be reported to the ruler inside and outside the country, at this time, are all listened to with words.

After the tasks are completed, he sits upright to face the court, surrounded by ten thousand ministers in front and behind, together managing the affairs of the state, issuing and receiving the king's words, listening to the matters until the end of the first period, for the latter two periods.
In the second period, he advances the king's meal, plays wonderful music, and enjoys various pleasures to delight the king's mind.

In the third period, he bathes, plays, and entertains. Ten billion palace ladies play music inside, with exceptional demeanor, surrounding him. With soft intentions and following orders, he always gives rise to a compassionate mind. The pure gardens and forests are decorated everywhere. Whether hearing or seeing, afflictions are eliminated.

Until the fourth period, in the king's main hall, he set up a Dharma seat adorned with various treasures. He sought everywhere in the kingdom for Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and those who had attained the fruits of the path who possessed great wisdom, to expound the true Dharma. He listened to their teachings, respectfully joined his palms, made prostrations and inquiries, and with a mind of utmost respect and reverence, invited them to sit.
Then he asked:
What are wholesome dharmas?
What are unwholesome dharmas?
What is right?ğŸ”½What is wrong?
What is harmful?
What is beneficial?
What should be done, he did. What should be stopped, he stopped.

He should also frequently gather wise and experienced ministers and reclusive sages of high virtue to consult with them and learn from them. Through this, he will attain wisdom and clarity, and can inquire about state affairs and evaluate their merits and faults.
Due to this, the king's virtue will gradually flourish and become perfect.
The beings in the country will gradually experience peace and happiness.
It can make worldly transformation the cause of liberation.
Why is this?
All the activities of the bodhisattvas are nothing but the Buddha's work.
It is like the waxing moon, gradually brightening until on the fifteenth day its light is full and shines everywhere;
It is also like the ocean tides, which begin to rise with the new moon and reach their greatest on the fifteenth day, with billowing waves extending for thousands of miles.
The Dharma King's governance is also like this. The king's virtue increases. Without a king, wise ministers and elders are like a boat without a captain, swirling and sinking.
It is also like sentient beings thirsting for timely rain, seeking the protection of Indra. Even if it does not rain for ten years, these sentient beings will not necessarily die.
But if there is no king, within a single day the myriad people will be in chaos, harming and destroying each other.
From this one should know that in protecting sentient beings, the king surpasses Indra.
Furthermore, because the king listens to the supreme Dharma, he always reflects and admonishes himself to transform the multitude.
Whenever he ascends the throne, his power is strong and fierce, and the king's virtue increases, subduing the neighboring strong ones.

Outwardly, he sets up various strict guards for the court, plays wonderful music, respectfully attends the king, and the king, together with the inner palace and retinue, surrounds him and sits on the lion throne;

His body and mind are fearless, like the sun emerging from clouds, shining brightly and freely, just like Indra the king of the gods residing among the celestial beings. He places four great men in the four corners of the palace, their bodies clad in golden armor like the four heavenly kings, left and right, attending and guarding, wielding various weapons, displaying the majestic virtue of our king. The king's will is inclusive, and his mind is humble towards the myriad people. He does not listen or watch, always thinking of acting in accordance.
Like the ocean swallowing the flowing rivers, like a mountain storing treasures, the music stops, and inside and outside, the mind is focused single-mindedly.

At that time, my king observed the various dignified demeanors and precious adornments of the ministers, knowing them to be like illusory transformations, and strengthened his mind. With a compassionate and gentle voice, he spoke a verse, saying:
'Assemblies are momentary, glory and wealth are impermanent,
Human life is like a flash of lightning, even the powerful all return to death.
The demon of death diminishes the full, impermanence destroys the jeweled mountain,
The supreme Dharma is always firm and solid, one should cultivate without negligence.'

After the king spoke the verse, he proclaimed to the ministers to each return to their usual positions, to manage the affairs of the kingdom, and to benefit sentient beings, with a mind free from laziness.
Good man, you should know that such is called the inner virtue of our king.
Sudhana said:
What is also called the external transformation of the king's virtue?
He replied:
Good man!
All sentient beings and the world are established and upheld, all due to the karmic retribution of sentient beings themselves and the virtue and power of the rulers of various countries.

At the beginning of the eon when this world was formed, humans were all born by transformation, with complete limbs and bodies, not relying on clothing or food, with full and perfect appearances, and radiant bodies. There was no distinction between day and night. As past afflictions became dominant, earth essence arose accordingly, and gradually natural fragrant rice appeared.

Later, a lord of the fields was established, and far and near returned to him together. He nurtured and governed impartially, becoming the Ká¹£atriya king. From then until now, the royal way has not been interrupted.
For those with desires, without a ruler there is chaos. When a country has a ruler, everyone finds peace. Therefore, it is said that the power of the king can protect sentient beings.
Know that humans have four castes:ğŸ”½1. The Brahmin caste, who mostly cultivate oral karma;
2. The Ká¹£atriya caste, who mostly cultivate manual labor;
Third are the Vaishyas, who mostly cultivate the land;
Fourth are the Shudras, who engage in menial labor.
The other miscellaneous classes, such as the Chandalas, mostly practice evil conduct.
However, these four castes and other miscellaneous classes have different occupations and places of residence. Although their work varies from youth to old age, they all revere four things.
What are the four?
First, cultivating arts and crafts; second, managing and acquiring wealth; third, enjoying desires together; fourth, each seeking liberation.
As for arts and crafts, from childhood to adulthood, each learns their craft in their own class.
If it is the occupation of a Brahmin, they cultivate wisdom, study writing, seals, astrology, physiognomy, good and bad fortune, and the Vedas.

The ká¹£atriya class, further cultivating archery and horsemanship, governs by nurturing people, their merit lies in restraining violence, they delight the masses with music, and punishment is not meted out in the court.
The vaiÅ›ya class cultivates fields, sows seeds, and plows, storing grain in granaries, the foundation of the human and heavenly countries.
The Å›Å«dra class engages in commerce, whether profitable or not, and travels to sell goods, focusing on increasing wealth.
As for those who engage in business, once their crafts and skills are perfected, they all strive to work for themselves.
Each, within their own group, competes in creating a livelihood.
As for those who enjoy pleasures, having abundant wealth and profit, they establish their homes, enjoy marriage and entertainment, and indulge in the pleasures of sound and color.
As for those who seek liberation, in brief there are two types:
First, the brahmin and ká¹£atriya royal classes;

His hair is already gray, and he is over fifty years old. His strength is declining, and his appearance is fading. He is tired of the world and seeks the Way. His feelings are deep in seeking liberation. Everyone says he is a true practitioner. Since what he practices is different, his teachers are also different. The ninety-six kinds each follow their original teachings, either seeking rebirth in the heavens or considering liberation.
Second, the disciples of the TathÄgata of the ÅšÄkya clan;
The practitioners of the three vehicles take the taste of immortality, cultivate compassion, and benefit all beings.
In this way, various heterodox and orthodox schools, lay and monastic, all rely on the king's country to abide and uphold.
They all spread the teachings because of our king. Therefore, the learners are like the potter's wheel and rope, and the skills they cultivate are like gathering clay.

The king's practice of correct teachings is like the potter shaping the clay, skillfully benefiting himself and others like making various vessels. If there were no royal power, meritorious practices would not be accomplished, and the Dharma would disappear without remainder. How much less could it benefit and save?
Moreover, one-sixth of all the merit they cultivate will always belong to the king.

The king's mountain of blessings is lofty and solid, difficult to destroy. As for the other external realms where the correct teaching is not practiced, the people within the country indulge in accumulating evil. Those who wish to cultivate goodness have no chance for temporary peace.
In this way, obstructing cultivation and creating unwholesomeness, one-sixth of the resulting evil karma will also belong to that king.
The king's mountain of offenses is firm and steep, difficult to destroy. Therefore, our king's blessings and wisdom are exceptional.
At that time, the brÄhman again said to Sudhana:
Have you not heard what the earth deity said?
The earth deity always says:
'I bear the entire earth, all that exists, and Mount Sumeru, and do not consider it heavy, nor do I feel weary. But I am always weary and reluctant to support three kinds of people.
What are the three?
First, those who harbor rebellious thoughts and plot to harm the king;
Second, those who think of abandoning their kind parents and being unfilial;
Third, those who deny cause and effect, slander the Three Jewels, destroy the Dharma wheel Sangha, and obstruct those who cultivate goodness;
Such three types of people, I am extremely troubled by, and I do not wish to endure them even for a single thought.
' Furthermore, our king spreads the right teachings, and all Buddhas protect him, not to mention dragons and spirits?
With this right mind, he can restrain all evils, like holding a hook and whip. Evil dharmas do not arise, and those who do no good in the world are transformed and subdued, practicing the right view;
It is also like the king of oxen. When the king moves, all the oxen follow.
The king is also like this. When the right teachings spread, all sentient beings follow them.
Moreover, an iron hook can restrain a mad elephant. The king's righteous rule can subdue evil people and ultimately lead them to liberation.
Furthermore, our king establishes the country and governs the people, always abiding in three things:
First, to eliminate the five fears, second, to carefully select the three ministers, and third, to diligently cultivate the imperial cuisine.
Why is this so?
When the ruler of a country nurtures the people, he first eliminates fear.
If the ministers possess sufficient virtue, they are able to assist and harmonize.
If the imperial cuisine is exquisite, it nourishes both the body and the people, teaching people to be loyal and filial, respecting the elders and the dignified.
Sudhana asked:
How is it that this country alone has no five fears?
He replied:
Virtuous one!
First, the king's virtue is simple and frugal, and his financial distribution is fair;
there is no fear of the king's greed and theft.
Second, the royal clan is upright and virtuous, not greedy for treasures;
there is no fear of the inner ministers oppressing.
Third, the officials follow their duties, and kindness fills their minds;
there is no fear of cruel officials harming.
Fourth, everyone is righteous and yielding, and the country has no deceit;
there is no fear of thieves stealing and robbing.
Fifth, the neighboring countries are harmonious, and they receive the wind and turn to transformation;
There are no external dangers or difficulties to fear.
In other countries, the five fears exist, and people are necessarily uneasy.
Therefore, our king's sage transformation extends to the outside.
Sudhana said, How does the king carefully select the three ministers?
He replied, Good sir!

Like the sun god, dwelling high in the sun palace, 42,000 yojanas above the ground, the people of the four continents do not see his form and color, but only receive the illumination of his light, gazing up at the sun's disc, all knowing where it is.
Our king's sagely virtue is like that sun's disc, with great clarity ruling the realm, no obscurity is not illuminated, opening up things and accomplishing tasks, discerning and removing confusion.

Ten thousand great ministers and a hundred million valiant generals are all illuminated by the king's light, serving the state's radiance, carefully selecting the three ministers, governing this hundred offices.
What are the three?
First, the assisting minister, second, the general, third, the envoy minister.

As for the ministers, they assist the king in governing, take over the king's administration of government, assist the king's virtue above, and care for the people below. They promote the worthy and employ the capable, keep their minds pure, and serve their posts, like the sun shining brightly, distinguishing the various parts.

As for the generals, the chief ministers in charge of the army must be loyal, sincere, deeply benevolent, righteous, virtuous, and upright. They are brave and resourceful, and do not fail in protecting sentient beings, removing evil, and making the basis firm, like the sun shining brightly, washing away darkness and dispelling confusion.

From the seventh month to the tenth month, they finally prepare the drums and train the troops. The troops are in order and solemn, and they strive to take advantage of the situation and follow the appropriate location for setting up camp.
In this way, the commander receives the order and leads the troops, attacking and defending in a timely manner, and the battles are always victorious.
You should also know that our country has five cities.
What are the five?
First, a mountain city, relying on high and dangerous terrain, with cliffs surrounding it;
Second, a water city, with moats formed by rivers, flowing around it in four directions;
Third, a sand city, vast and far-reaching, with no water or grass outside;
Fourth, an earth city, with solid walls and high ramparts, filled with military provisions inside;
Fifth, a human city, with a wise ruler and virtuous ministers, deep strategies and far-reaching plans.
These five cities are of equal measure, but the human city is the most superior, revered by our country.
Therefore, our great king abides in inconceivable spiritual powers and wondrous transformations.
The three envoys refer to:

The envoy who travels to receive messages in the four directions, going back and forth with the king's orders, like the sun shining on the envoy, its light flowing through the plains and valleys, with nothing private in the dark ravines.
Why is this so?

Because the king's virtue is refined and subtle, and the king dwells in the profound and secret, the myriad directions do not see him, and the four seas do not know him. It is all due to the envoys proclaiming the king's grace, with different regions submitting and the eight directions revering and following. Those who are not at peace are made at peace, and those who are already at peace do not regress.
Therefore, our king, together with the elders, prime ministers, and great ministers, carefully selects the capable and scrutinizes the matters.
In short, a king's envoy must possess ten virtues to be competent.

First, to be loyal and faithful, second, to love and respect one's ruler and parents, third, to have a strong memory and extensive knowledge, fourth, to have broad discernment and understanding, fifth, to have versatile eloquence, sixth, to be proficient in both internal and external matters, seventh, to be humble, kind, and yielding, eighth, to be upright and flawless, ninth, to have an exemplary demeanor that stands out from the crowd, and tenth, to understand the king's secret intentions.

Possessing these ten virtues, one receives the mandate to proclaim authority. Wherever one travels, one keeps the body pure and solitary, not indulging in alcohol or sex, not sleeping in crowded dwellings. In the drunken state or while sleeping, one guards against leaking state secrets.

When sent on a mission to neighboring countries, one must convey the king's words without being swayed by profit or intimidated by authority. One's actions, concealment, advancement, and retreat must all be in accord with the right time. One adapts to local customs and conditions, guiding the people to transform themselves, and in the king's strategies and tactics, one fully understands without doubt. One strives to manifest one's abilities to comfort the different peoples.

Because of these three ministers, the king's virtuous influence is accomplished, transforming evil and revealing goodness, with his authority extending to the myriad directions, like the sun's light illuminating objects and dispelling darkness, with far and near all illuminated.

Therefore, in our country, receiving the sage influence of the king, there are many virtuous people, with their movements and stillness appropriate. Whether traveling or staying, they do not associate with evil people.
They are called:

Those who deny cause and effect, abandon loyalty and filial piety, have little compassion by nature, delight in seeing others' faults, are lowly and vulgar, are not afraid of wrongdoing, have much desire and anger, have no shame or conscience, have a stubborn nature and are timid, and are jealous of those who are superior and capable. Such people are all not closely associated with, nor do they ride unruly and untamed vicious elephants and horses;
They also do not tame or raise useless birds and beasts;
They also do not travel through deep mountains, great marshes, empty villages, graveyards, wildernesses, mountain dangers, where vicious beasts and non-humans dwell;
He also did not look directly at wine shops, slaughterhouses, or places of debauchery.
If he encountered a supremely auspicious event, he would circumambulate it clockwise and pay homage.
In order to protect his blessings, he never stepped on the shadows or footprints of the Buddha, the Dharma, the Saá¹…gha, his parents, teachers, or elders.
He respectfully paid homage to those who were venerable and virtuous, without any arrogance in his mind.

He saw the Buddha's stupas, temples, monasteries, the abodes of sages and saints, and the dwellings of superior people, and he himself encouraged others to follow and revere them, to repair and complete them.
Because of this, the devas and nÄgas all gave rise to joy, the wind and rain were timely, the five grains were abundant, and the people were at peace and happy.
The loyal and good people who served the king were able to approach him, while flatterers, villains, and the cruel were unable to get close to him.
It was like a sandalwood forest, surrounded by sandalwood trees, without any thorny shrubs.
It was like the Anavatapta Pond, with fragrant and virtuous waters, without any salty tastes.
The king keeps away from evil people in the same way.
It is not like sweet fruits hidden by fierce beasts.
Sudhana said again:
What kind of person is suitable to be in charge of the royal kitchen?
He replied:
Good sir!
A person in charge of the royal kitchen should possess ten virtues.
What are the ten?

First, pure lineage; second, well-regulated body, speech, and mind; third, complete loyalty and filial piety; fourth, trust, yielding, and humility; fifth, understanding the king's dietary nature; sixth, skillfully understanding dietary restrictions; seventh, well-regulated body and taste; eighth, knowing the king's mealtime; ninth, understanding the king's food, whether sweet or poisonous, and also being able to remove them; tenth, knowing the appropriate food for day and night, month and season.
Possessing these ten virtues, one may be in charge of the royal kitchen.
Measure the servants and the place for preparing food, keeping it pure, fragrant, and clean, and supervise without violation.
The brahmin said:
You should also know that I always think that in the heavens and among humans, I observe that all the superior ones possess all kinds of virtues, and my sage king is no exception.
What does this mean?
You should know that the lion, the king of beasts, has one supreme virtue, which is being free from two minds.
When killing a great elephant, he uses all his strength;
when killing other small animals, he also uses all his strength.
Our king is also like this. He does not fear great matters and does not belittle small matters. He uses all the power of compassion and wisdom to the end, leaving nothing behind.
You should know that the king of water birds possesses two virtues:
First, his mind is discerning. When catching fish, he enters the water, stands on tiptoe, and watches single-mindedly, motionless.
Second, he observes the water creatures with tranquility, and all that he desires comes to him.
Our king is also like this. He resides high above and looks down, listening to the governance of the myriad directions;
Silent and unmoving, responding to all without obstruction, his words are never empty, and everything is accomplished by itself.
The brÄhman said:
You should also know that our king has three virtues, and his sagely transformation spreads like the golden wheel. He is like a well-trained horse king with three merits.
What are the three?
First, his mind is gentle and his strength can go far;
Second, he is not afraid of cold or heat, and can remain safe in dangerous situations;
Third, he is easy to serve and always knows when to stop.
Our king is also like this. First, his words are always gentle and true, benefiting people with the Dharma, teaching and transforming sentient beings to ultimately accomplish them;
Second, he is diligent in governing the people, his mind has no danger or ease, and he can give away his precious wealth to provide for all;
Third, he is greatly wise and brave, subduing all enemies, and his taxes are reasonable, always knowing when to stop.
Endowed with these three virtues, fanned by the gentle breeze, other countries fear his might, and his own realm cherishes his kindness.
The brÄhmaá¹‡a said:

First, setting up trust and being the rooster to announce the dawn; second, guarding righteousness and distributing food equally; third, facing the enemy and showing courage; fourth, not following the female chickens.
Our king is also like this. First, rewards and punishments are timely; second, all directions are equally saved; third, righteousness subdues the strong; fourth, he does not listen to internal words.
Endowed with these four virtues, the transformation benefits all without boundary.
The brÄhmaá¹‡a said:
You should also know that our king's five virtues and sagely transformations flow like the five merits of the good time goose king in the desire heaven.
What are the five?
First, there is a time for mating; second, calling out without fear; third, seeking food in moderation; fourth, the mind is not negligent; fifth, not accepting the flattering words of other birds.
Our king is also like this;
First, he has a pure mind and few desires, not indulging the inner palace.
Second, his words are prudent and true, and no one outside disobeys his orders.
Third, he takes and gives without error, ensuring clothing and food.
Fourth, he regulates his mind and inspects the path, leaving faults and diligently practicing.
Fifth, he accomplishes the correct mind, not associating with flattery and deceit.
Endowed with these five virtues, his kindness extends to the eight wildernesses.
The brÄhman said:
You should also know that our king's six virtues and sagely transformations flow like the six virtues of the excellent dog king in the Magadha country.
What are the six?

First, eating whatever is obtained; second, being content with little; third, sleeping peacefully; fourth, easily waking up when grass moves; fifth, having the same mind toward the poor and the rich; sixth, bravely preventing theft.
Our king is also like this: First, the myriad lands offer tribute according to their land, without disagreement;
Second, during times of scarcity, he always feels ashamed when receiving little;
Third, what is done is auspicious, and it is easy to sleep peacefully;
Fourth, right views are in the mind, and thoughts are immediately aware;
Fifth, respect for the virtuous and elders, and compassion for the poor and lowly;
Sixth, thoughts of all beings, protecting them at all times, majestic and courageous, free from all troubles and difficulties.
Endowed with these six virtues, the myriad people have the same mind.
Thinking of this, all things become virtues. I praise our king, whose fame is lofty and far-reaching.
Well-disciplining beings, diligent and not lax.
In this way, the twenty-one supreme virtues that the king is able to practice are increased in number.
All enemies will naturally disperse.
No foreign invaders can enter the country.
You should also know that if there are those who lack these twenty-one virtues but have only three virtues, they can also govern well.
First, being able to distribute precious wealth to provide for all;
Second, being willing to give up one's life without false speech;
Third, possessing great courage and valor, able to subdue enemies.
If one lacks these three but has only one virtue, one can still govern and transform, namely having great blessings and virtues.
Such a benevolent king is the best.

It is like the eighty-four thousand Dharma gates ultimately returning to the ultimate truth. The king is also like this, with various extraordinary strategies ultimately returning to blessings and virtues.
If the king has blessings, the king's country will be peaceful and harmonious, without trouble or affairs.
Sentient beings will be wealthy and happy, and the transformation will extend to the myriad directions.
In the near term, it benefits body and mind, and in the distant future, it is the same as liberation.
It is accomplished by the king's compassionate blessings and benevolent kindness. I extensively explain that our king's wonderful practices are inexhaustible.

Are originally unable to be intimate with.ğŸ”½If there are those who give rise to deceitful intentions,

Actions that accord with the people's minds, abandoning evil and following goodness.
Loving people as one loves oneself, leading oneself to follow others,
When the nine clans follow the wind, the hundred officials follow the king's governance.
The eight directions return to the sage's transformation, governing with no action,
Pushing merit and reasoning the mind, the still mind has never been without affairs.
Loyal ministers assist my lord, following movement like an arm and a rib,
The myriad states reach sagacity and brightness, the four seas praise the lord's virtue.
Faithfully receiving the teachings of the buddhas, using the Dharma to awaken sentient beings,
Causing them to understand their own minds, like the sun shining on lotus flowers blooming.
The people of the country protect my lord, just as the king protects the people of the country,
Like a forest guarding the king of beasts, the beasts protect the forest and wilderness.
Other countries have many fears, the king's greed and favored ministers,
Cruel officials falsely accuse the innocent, thieves and bandits openly steal and rob,
The realm has four afflictions, and external enemies will surely invade.
Our king is pure inside and out, and the people of the country have no five fears.
There are four kinds of work in the world: first, wisdom; second, precious wealth;
Third, enjoying the five desires; fourth, seeking liberation.
Many kings do not possess these, and when they die, people do not praise them,
Like the wind holding a bellows bag, when the wind stops, life follows and ends.
Our king is equipped with the four dharmas, and the virtue of wisdom shines on his body,
Rich in wonderful treasures, he helps the poor and destitute.
The five desires are unmatched, and he is unstained like a lotus flower,
But he attracts sentient beings and later causes them to enter the Buddha's wisdom.
Abiding in the liberation of illusion, he manifests himself in greed and anger,
Transforming to deal with evil people, causing them all to turn towards the Buddha's path.
Before long, you will see the various skillful means,
Ultimately benefiting sentient beings, therefore the sound resounds far.
Subtle wisdom as the wind, always commanding, eternally inexhaustible,
You should quickly look up to him, do not give rise to a lazy mind.
Seeing a superior wise person once, surpasses dwelling for a hundred thousand years,
Some may have a lifespan of a thousand years, always eating what is discarded by humans.
Not knowing the affairs of the three periods of time, and also lacking the treasures of the Dharma and wealth,
Filling the belly with the mind of desire for sustenance, human form and animals are no different.
Little learning or the mind is lofty, easily satisfied like a cow's hoofprint,
Like a rat holding things in its hands, considering itself able to do much.
The ocean of wisdom is vast and difficult to measure, not comprehending it increases slander,
A cow drinks water and it becomes milk, a snake drinks water and it becomes poison.
Learning wisdom leads to enlightenment, learning foolishness leads to birth and death,
Not understanding this, it is due to the fault of little learning.
Hearing much without weariness or laziness,
Our king has many assisting ministers, and the city is also secure.
Abundant wealth, many soldiers and horses, neighboring countries are all friendly and good,
Thus possessing the seven branches, the brave and wise always rely on them.
In the human and heavenly realms, various supreme merits,
Benefiting all sentient beings, as proclaimed above.
The wise person hears one meaning, and the related categories are vast and boundless,
In brief, for the Dharma King, taming the body and peacefully governing the myriad people.
The glory of the world is always not declining, the wondrousness beyond the world is inconceivable,
Like the ocean receiving the flowing rivers, embracing and increasing in depth and breadth.
